column10: developers are Asshats screwing the game over while out of ore strides ahead an outpaces this trashy game that doesn't listen to its community. NO multiplayer support or any new machines or mining equipment or maps, same garbage for the last several years!

The new hard mode addition was a good move & also the implementation of breakdown & repairs, were both great new additions and pushed this title in the right direction.

However its down hill from here,

The game is majorly lacking content & is still troubled with shocking frames & many various bugs which the devs have not tried to fix.The townships have no presence of Ai and the detail on the buildings and cars are horrible. the devs have also expressed that they wont be improving towns or adding Ai, i know this is a simulation title but unfortunetly in its current state i cant recommend Gold Rush even on sale.

"Revisited this title in 2024" "6 Years Later!!

I have a RTX 3060 16GRAM Running SSD  critical low frames, so bad at times it almost brings Gold Rush to a grinding halt, sad that its only the real Gold prospecting sim out there for people and it is mostly unplayable, if it wasn't so badly optimised with a shocking frame rates, it would be half decent. partly the game engine, but mostly poor optimisation.

Sadly its still a big no.
fore sure a fun game and i cant wait to get the dlc to make it more efficent , for sure buy the game if your looking for a new game

Game is good over all. Its a nice grind kind of. 
I suggest to play this game in costum settings.
Take your first few nuggets othervise you will shovel like a maniac for multiple hours to get enough money to actually start the game loop in a satisfying way. 
Then play without nuggets and on 12x speed, and switch malfunctions and pressure system on, if you like to handle clunky mashines keep easy washplant placing off. i would recommend to switch it on. its a pain in the ass, main reason because mashines are not well on mnk. 

Big Cons:
No multi-player
No AI-Workers
Bad Physics
Bad performance (sometimes)
Not much freedom to do do things in your way.
Low variaty in mashines
No costumazations (there are a few but just ugly)

Overall: I love simulations and this one is nice because of the setting, but not because of its mechanics.

Setting: 10/10
Game Loop: 6/10
Progression: 2/10

You dont get the feeling of getting things done:
Its dig a hole to dig bigger hole.

Edit: 120 hrs in, i can tell: Dont waste your time! I was (literally) digging deep into it and what i found is a unbalanced, unsatisfying, stupid mess of a game with too little content.

It's really sad because this is a great game concept and you can tell a lot of thought went into it, but using this (CPU incentive) UNITY game engine was its downfall. This game is so badly optimized compared to other games it's not even funny and if that wasn't enough then you get the bugs to come and entertain you some more. I run the most demanding triple A  games available today at MAX settings and top FPS on my high end PC and I can't run this one without constant stuttering and frame rate going from 130 FPS all the way down to 10 FPS. Don't get me wrong, the game is still worth a try, but for the reasons I mentioned I just can't recommend this game unless you get it really cheap.

It's QUITE clunky and the driving visuals sometimes make me nauseous (that's just me though, I'm a bit sensitive to that stuff) but it is strangely addictive...  I love loading dirt with the excavator and reaping the golden reward for my hard work.  Worth it for $15 or less...

Best get it at a discount. It's not a bad game, but it is very outdated at this point. Graphics are not good, controls are clunky IMO, especially with driving vs work modes, lags every time you drive (I have higher end PC), etc. New developers that are a little active, but refuse to consider MP or mod support. Therein lies my issue - this is single player only, and the AI "workers" cannot help you - they are ephemeral and just give  you tiny bonuses to what you do. Made it to T3 washplant and upgraded equipment and I can't continue to do it all my own. Everything is parsed down to details so you have to turn on water and power and wash every mat. From a simulation standpoint, this is great. From a player perspective, this is not fun by myself. It is not fun to me to have to continuously jump back and froth between equipment and do every single little things myself because there is no AI and no MP. It's not even kind of long periods - I mean constantly going back and forth between the excavator and dump truck, as an example. Give me at least a way to simulate and pretend a worker is helping me - maybe a button to empty the truck into the wash plant feeder, as an example. Ruins some immersion and simulation, but at least I would play if it did not literally feel like work instead of having fun playing a game. Recommend folks check out farm sim and the various mods that allow things like mining with a ton of equipment options, better controls, and with useful AI and multiplayer options.

I bought this game shortly after it came out about 7 years ago but refunded it cause  of many issues : Bugs! SO Many Bugs!

The bouncy truck you drive around in, bouncy bouncy Zero suspension, the damn thing had no weight whatsoever. My bloody shadow weighs more! When you are parked and want to move forward or back, the entire vehicle does nothing for half a second and then shoots off at light speed and slams into things, bouncing all the while doing it! 

When you drive from one location to the next, the entire game freezes for 3 seconds while everything loads in, then abruptly continues.

Oh and lets not forget about the graphics that make the entire game look like someone vomited a Jackson Pollock painting all over the screen - Jayzuz!   This game looked bad for 2011 let alone 2017 when it was first release, and Nothing has improved on this point....

Late 2023 - bought it again.
Actually, Nothing has improved on Any point. 
The truck still floats on the road like a soap bubble. Still has Zero weight and is Still like driving/steering a feather in a stiff breeze.
The graphics are an utter mess Still. They Need to move over to a new graphics engine.
For a game about digging for gold, the terrain deformation is Terrible! This should have been fixed back in 2017 when the game was released! 
I like the idea of this game very much, I really want it to work, but until these continued issues have been fixed properly, new games like Out of Ore will jump ahead and surpass this game because it's taking SO long to get anything fixed.
It's like the Devs just gave up and went home the day after its initial release.

I like this game. If you want to know how to boost your productivity, forcing your brain to eliminate every single useless movement including the ones in real life, go for it. It's pretty addicting for my brain.
But there are so many "but", it's even hard for me to track 'em all for this review. I'll cut it short: I've bought this title a couple of years ago, it was 30th of April 2021: it was a mess. Random, oscillating performances, very little else to do but grinding. I remember I've told myself: i'll be back in a while, waiting for it to be polished and implemented with something else to do, some npcs, since there's NONE. 3 years are passed and honestly... there are a couple of work machines more, a couple of skins and some spare parts more, but there are the same performance issues and basically the game looks and feels the same it was back then. WIth both my rigs, settings upped at max, my cpu sits at 35%, my gpu at 40%, and i have from 170 fps to 30, then 60, 90 then again up to 150/170 in a matter of seconds, then goes again. The more you play, the more fps drop, until you are forced to restart the game, losing precious seconds you could've dedicate to... grinding, of course.  
I don't think i have the power to speed the updates up, so buy it if you feel too: the game is fun. And you'll probably do exactly what you'd expect to do buying a game like this. Just know that you probably won't see many things change too soon, to say the least.

I've played this game pretty much since it came out.  Its needed lots of work the entire game.  Though I do enjoy playing it, it needs lots of work.  For example:
No Multiplayer feature - This game would rise to the top if it had multiplayer.  Nothing like running 3 machines, the wash plant and having to make constant runs to town all by yourself.  Anybody who knows gold mining, if the the wash plant is not running, you're not making money.
Better Machine Physics - Nothing like getting your 20,000 Lb bulldozer getting stuck on a tiny piece of dirt. Also, they have independent arm control on the blade, making it where you can grade at an angle, where the game makes you move the entire blade or not at all.

All in all The game COULD be good, but right now it's super boring as you can only play by yourself or vs a bunch of others in a leader board that are also by themselves.

I'll play it again IF they ever make it multiplayer.  Until then, I'll play the slightly lesser Gold Hunter that IS multiplayer

14 Dec, 2020I wrote a review where the game was bugged, where it wouldn't load when I have played for 129 hours.  I write this in 2024 and I am happy to say the game has gotten better and stable.  It is fun to sit and relax if that is your thing or go at it hard and fast.

*edit*
So the devs started working on technical problems and seem to have an interest again in caring about the game. In the test environment I noticed some good improvements with the lag and FPS situation and it made the game far more enjoyable. Still there is lots of work to do. 

*edit #2*
Studio has been reshuffled and they are working on new content. Looking forward to it. So far my advise would be, if you're into the whole gold mining, setting up everything and able to withstand the monotone work. Go for it, for that genre it is probably the only available option at the moment. If you're just curious...watch some gameplay on youtube to see if this rubs you the right way.

After the first content drop I will decide if I change to recommended or not.

It's like taking a shit and pulling it apart to look for undigested corn.

Though I absolutely love the game, there are difficulties with it.
For starters, the deformation of the terrain leaves much to be desired. There are times when you can "destroy" dirt you are attempting to run through the washplant, simply by connecting the excavator bucket with the wall of your hole in a certain way. (Side of the bucket below the lip of the hole.) Another way to "destroy" terrain is by simply pushing or dumping it on the non-digging area. Your dirt will simply disappear, thus keeping anyone from creating a stockpile area.
Last but not least, after so many hours of playing this game, and I will likely have many more, the lack of even co-op or the creators allowing modders to attempt a co-op mod, the game gets insanely boring in a relatively short period of time. If you're into single-player games with mind-numbing repetition, this is the game for you. Otherwise, save your money. Only buy this game for when you really feel like kicking back and being a potato.

The game has so much potential and has pretty awesome mechanics, still cant play it with this crappy performance.

Was super excited to get this. Bought it, installed and as soon as I got to the title screen I knew this was going to be a mediocre experience at best. Game UI feels very half ass put together. The tutorial is an absolute fucking joke. It's day two and I'm still stuck because the instructions are dog shit. I'm being told to do this and that like I'm supposed to know where everything is and what the objects are. I'm not a fucking miner I don't know what any of this stuff is. Like the first instruction is to take the car off a hill but the wording is so mistranslated it just doesn't make sense. I'm not going to ask for my money back and I will play the game with all its issues but I'm just disappointed. I found this game from searching on YouTube for mining games 2023. How was this made in 2017 and yet the tutorial still hasn't been fixed since then?! This feels like a 3-6 month beta game and should be priced as such. If there's one nice thing I must say it's the models are really nice and physics feels realistic. Also thank you for making a mining game but for gods sake fix your game.

It's captivating. Be warned tho, it doesnt have much variety, gameplay or action or anything of that sort. Its more of a tribute to the TV show and the fans. It has a lot of detail and very well captures that spirit of gold mining - its long and difficult, grueling process with lots of setback. That's what this game does great. You dont play this for finishing or "completing" anything, you play for playing sake. If you enjoy hardcore sims, akin to Euro Truck or similar, then this IS for you. If you are looking for something exciting and polished - then its not for you.

I think I have enough time in the game to add a review. First and for most I am a fan of gold rush and part of the reason I purchased the game. I also am a fan of grindy games with leader boards. Gives something to work for. This game is both of those. If the developer would add bigger maps and more equipment I think this game would be hard to beat. Another plus would be able to play with friends. One person in a dozer, one person in a loader, one person in a dumper. Or however you want to do it. Create a leader board for multiplayer maps. I'm really torn on recommending this game, for a number of reason.

At it's core it's digging dirt and washing it, more or less just like the show. At times, it feels just like the show. You're desperate for money and you know the one thing you need to do: run pay dirt. But things just keep going wrong. Everything's breaking, or that cleanup was dramatically smaller than it should be. Is there a setup problem or are you just not on the gold?

Unfortunately, like a lot of niche games this ends up being a pretty janky experience. The performance sucks. FPS is fine but driving around the map is met with loading hangups, huge amounts of pop-in for terrain features, and a render distance of about 10 feet for most place-able or drive-able objects. But none of that is unexpected for this something like this, and if you like the core loop can easily be overlooked.

However, the game is not without it's bigger issues, and extremely questionable decisions.

 1. The loan system is totally worthless, and possibly broken. Just looking at the loans should discourage you from ever bothering, but sometimes you are in a tight spot and don't have much of a choice. But here's where I'm confused: Take a $60k at 21% interest at 23:30. At midnight I somehow had a $24k payment due. At 11:00 that same game day I go to pay the loan off for....$102k? Just pretend loans aren't in the game.

2. The vehicles barely work with their terrain system at times. I'm driving a front loader with wheels larger than my real-life car, and it gets constantly stuck on the tiniest patches of deformed terrain. If the terrain is on bedrock there's maybe a 50/50 shot as to whether you can actually get a machine to engage it and remove it. If it's not on bedrock you are just as likely to screw up the terrain beyond all usable condition if you try to fix it.

3. The pressure system is just...yeah. It rains for 12 hours non-stop and then like clockwork at noon your water source dries up because it hits a sweltering...80 F?  It's a system patched in later that tried to encourage the use of high-tier water supply gear...but it's not even half-baked...its just straight raw. The only real effect is to make you effectively only able to play the game during night time. Thankfully it can be toggled off at any time. Just do it from the start, it adds nothing to the game.

4. The upgrade path for equipment is really shallow, with half of it locked behind DLC. With the exception of the excavator there is 1 vehicle to serve each purpose. But we're not gonna count that because the small excavator is completely worthless and should be skipped. I'm not asking from Farming Sim levels of gear, but something more substantial would have been nice.

All that said, I do enjoy the game and will continue playing it. I don't really know why, but I dig. It's a game that offers a limited experience that you can't really get elsewhere, even if it's got problems and some boneheaded design decisions.

This makes it so unenjoyable to continue playing. So yeah I still can't recommend this game...

It’s a  enjoyable -unusual- sim/game. Let down by a very bad engine. Digging with the excavator is like digging concrete! 
The premise though still gives you great reward as you can enable very easy mode or whatever mode suits you.
As for tutorials. There is a tutorial in the in-built manual/guide. It tells you exactly what to set up (equipment needed) as you advance through the plots of land. It even shows you how they fit together. 
The vehicles need repair, inc jacking up to remove wheels, engine parts, filters on generators and the ability to shop for parts and sell gold nuggets or get them smelted into gold bars. Everything pretty much in real life is carried out by you in the game. Inc connecting water pipes and electrical connections correctly. Everything runs off generators and consumes fuel which you can go into town and fill up a bowser and Jerry cans. It’s satisfying hitting pay dirt and a nugget. It’s slow and very time consuming, but that is the nature of the game and real life. 
As I said, the engine is the weakest point. It struggles to load areas/textures when you go into to town, but when on site it’s fine, to a degree. There’s a lot of heavy machinery and equipment to buy or rent and a lot to do to keep you occupied. It’s definitely a love/hate game.
Regardless, i cannot recommend it for the main feature of the game -digging. The soil engine is utter garbage. Explosives would be the better option.

[h1]2018 vs. 2023: A Tale of Unimproved Frustration[/h1]
Started playing this in 2018. It was a poorly optimized game with bad controls and essentially an overly complicated micromanagement game with very little guidance.

Tried it again in 2023, and I can safely it still is a very poorly optimized game with bad controls, essentially an overly complicated micromanagement game, and very little guidance.

[b]Don't waste your time with this. Frustration awaits.[/b]

And reviews are also likely faked; most of the positive reviews follow the same pattern: one-line sentences with profiles that have 1-4 reviews in total, all in lowercase, no dot's at the end.... Someone should report this to Steam.

This game is very addictive. I just started playing it about two weeks ago and have about 120 hours in it, not much considering others play time. 

The biggest improve the DEVS could do would be to add multiplayer. I understand it isn’t being considered due to what it would take to write the code, but the fact is still the same. The game would be better with multiplayer. 

Working on the workers, I think would be a plus as well. I need played the original version of the game when workers found gold for you. I don’t want an NPC playing the game for me or doing all the work, but I do feel the DEVS went from one extreme to the other. I feel a better solution would have been a percent system. Based on how many workers you have, depended on the percent of hold found. If you did have one worker which only worked 48% of the time, then maybe find an extremely low amount of gold. In turn costing you money, due to the contract. If it was one worker at 86% of the time. Maybe he would find find an ounce to a few ounces an hour. And this multiplies based on works but by fragments of percents, not leaps and bounds. Also a HUGE improve for the DEVS would be to see these NPCs.

I also feel the loan system at the bank needs to be redone. The interested set when the loan is taken remains the same, whether you pay it off early or not. The interest should be recalculated if paid off early to avoid interest, just like in real life.

The DEVS  should also consider adding a leasing system to the equipment as well. A lot of new miners can afford to straight up buy new equipment and lease it. Also, adding more options, when it comes to upgrading to larger machinery. I understand they are avoiding licensing fees and not naming them real things but if they have a small dozer like the D9 to the D10 would be a cool stepping stone. 

Also, if you could purchase new or used pick up trucks, I feel it would increase the excitement as well. It would add another element to work at and would distract some players to spend money on something besides the claim. Which would bring them back to the claim to work harder, due to lack of funding. Same goes to living conditions. If you could have various trailers to sleep in and just like the “dirtiness,” you could add the possibility to building various sizes of housing on the claim.

I love the fact that you can lease then own the claims but they should have different size claims. All the claims are all the same size with higher and higher quantities of gold. If you could have various quantities of magnetite on the different claims. That way, if you goal is to upgrade the blacksmith. Maybe you would need to purchase a small claim which is high in magnetite but low or moderate in gold, but was a lot cheaper due to what would come out of the claim.

If you adjust the “dirtiness of the parcel” to various stages and you have to improve it would be very exciting. For example, if you could upgrade the tent to a crummy shack, then to a nice shack with nice wood, to a rough looking out building, to a nice out building, to trailer, to building, and FINALLY, etc...

Lastly, at least for this post is, what in the hell, happened to this town and community? Is this some post apocalyptic town when one man minds gold and pays for mining equipment and machinery to nonexistent people? Why does this environment look like we are in the third stage of poverty? I love the setting and it looks amazing. But I feel like they did all this work and then plopped this “town” on the back drops. I’m not saying to not be proud of what was created but, don’t just do “this” to move to something else. The DEVS have worked so hard to make it to this, which is an amazing product in-progress, but I feel the town is just this thing in limbo. Add a few elements to it. Don’t make it look like garbage is everywhere. The Police Department looks like that is ground zero for the atom bomb for god sake. If your adding the ability to buy new trucks, then make a dealership where you run up to the door, press “e” and a catalog system opens. You don’t have to generate all the playable trucks until the player decides which to purchases the rest of the trucks and cars in the game can, for now anyways, be generic and as they are.

To all reading, thank you for taking the time and please feel free to comment. Agree or disagree, we are all different and I support your views.

 To the fans of this game, let’s continue to provide ideas for improves, so the DEVS see this project is worth working on and making big changes on.

To the DEVS, in NO WAY am I try to “slam” you or “make fun” of what you have worked so hard on. This game and project is amazing and has an extreme amount of potential. This topic of gold mining, may have a pretty small dedicated fan base. But what this game can become would expand it. You’re doing great work and please put out some game improves which would bring back some players, instead of the random bug fixes. A DLC or few would help fund some projects for this game.

For now fans, keep digging and to the DEVS, keep up the great positive work!

Apart from setting up the machines on your land, all you do is put dirt in boxes. The worst part is that you don't even feel satisfied with this tedious work since 1- you don't see the gold ore flowing anywhere, just some boring dirt. You can only see the (very small and underwhelming) gold ingot that you bring down the road from the blacksmith to the bank to sell. For a game about gold, you don't see lots of it.  2- The vehicles you use to dig are painful to operate, and its all you use as soon as you reach the middle game. 3- It's not even nice to look at : usually it never bothers me, but here for some reason its really bad. You start the game during winter with the filthiest snow texture I have ever seen in a video game, and the dirt wich you spend 90% of your time digging and walking on has a terrible texture as well. 4- The gameplay loop gets boring very quickly. You buy new equipment, set it up, put the dirt in the machine, the machine sorts it, you go smelt the ore into bars, sell the bar and repeat. Only thing that changes throughout the game is the size of the machines you operate.
Finally it doesn't run well: I get a lot of freezes and it can crash pretty easily. Not fun.

This game was something i just could not stop playing the first 10 hours or so i had it, then i got kinda bored of it, but then came a new update and i started up again and spend another 10 hours or so, now yet another major update was released and i started up again and i must say that ofcause it's really repetitive since its digging for gold, Digging, being the key word, now one shouldn't expect any thing else if one just think a little about what the game is about.

Graphics is actually really good even if not playing on highest settings, the game might not run completely smoothly even with really decent hardware, but this is really not that noticeable since a little lower framerate now and then really doesn't cause any staggering or any thing atleast not from what i've experienced.

Now the reason i have chosen not to recommend this game is because it is still really buggy and the movement mechanics really can be wierd and annoying at times, albeit this is mostly when NOT in machinery. One more thing that i think really should atleast just be a consideration by the Devs is the oh so dreaded MP, now the devs have already said that this will not be a thing since it would require too much rewritting of the game and i'm sure there are other reasons too.

All in all i would give this game a 5/10 since it for the most part really does compensate for the cons, and i know this really isn't a in depth review, but hey i'm not a reviewer so this is mostly jsut my opinion. Feel free to critisice me if u should decide so.

Pro: A good single player gold digging simulator. (Edit: Basically the best gold digging simulator out there.)

Con: Would be so much better with a multiplayer/coop feature, but the developers won't rewrite 50% of the code to make it happen. 

Pro outweighs con. 

EDIT: Correct me if I'm wrong, but this is still the best gold digging simulator game out there. Would love to play similar type of games if anyone has any suggestions, please let me know in the comments. Thanks!

EDIT#2: Here's a part of my review of Construction Simulator, which I hated: 

Ok, reinstalled it and played for perhaps 15 minutes before uninstalling it again.
If you're a solo player, I'd recommend taking a look at (Gold Rush) if you haven't already. 
Don't expect frequent updates or multiplayer (I haven't played a game where I wanted multiplayer more, but it won't happen). While there's some snapping for major equipment like trommels, shakers and duplex jigs, and mandatory delivery for bigger vehicles like excavators and the dumper, everything else needs to be physically picked up at the store and transported to the claims/sites. You'll need to connect hoses of different size and decide their path, it's the same with electric cables. Equipment will consist of parts (Springs, cables, wheels, batteries, cogs, tubes, buttons etc etc) that can break down and need switching out. It's not a perfect game, could be better optimized, but there's a lot of content for a fairly low price, it's given me hundreds of hours (300+) of entertainment. Up until Construction Simulator, GH has been (correct me if I'm wrong) the best excavator "simulator" out there imo.

So CS might have better ground physics and more excavators to choose from, but the auto-completion of jobs takes away every sense of accomplishment. It basically deletes everything you've done and puts in the creation of the developers, wether it's a hole in the ground, a flat surface, a tree, a wall, cargo pallet placement, etc, etc etc. In GH you have to plan the whole worksite and I think it's really rewarding seeing the claim evolve as you get more equipment on site and the whole place forming into a quarry as you dig deeper and bigger, making it more into your creation instead of the developer's.

[h1]Introducing Gold Rush: The Game - Experience the Thrill of Gold Mining[/h1]

Have you ever dreamt of striking it rich, discovering hidden treasures, and embarking on an exciting adventure? If you're fascinated by the allure of gold mining and the thrill of the hunt, then Gold Rush: The Game is the perfect virtual experience for you. Get ready to don your mining gear, roll up your sleeves, and dive into the world of gold prospecting like never before.

[h2]Unveiling the Gold Rush: The Game[/h2]

Gold Rush: The Game is an immersive simulation game that allows you to step into the boots of a hardworking gold miner. Developed by a passionate team of game developers, this virtual gold mining adventure promises to deliver a unique and realistic experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

[h2]Digging into Gameplay[/h2]

When it comes to gameplay, Gold Rush: The Game truly shines. From the moment you start playing, you'll find yourself captivated by the attention to detail and the authenticity of the gold mining process. You begin with a small claim in the Alaskan wilderness, armed with basic tools and a dream of striking it big.

The game offers a variety of activities, allowing you to experience every aspect of the gold mining process. From digging and panning for gold to operating heavy machinery like excavators and wash plants, you'll need to master the skills required to extract the precious metal from the earth. As you progress, you can upgrade your equipment, expand your operation, and take on more challenging tasks.

[h2]The Realistic Gold Mining Experience[/h2]

One of the standout features of Gold Rush: The Game is its remarkable attention to detail and realism. The developers have gone above and beyond to recreate the sights, sounds, and challenges of gold mining. The game's graphics are stunning, bringing to life the beauty of the Alaskan wilderness and the intricacies of the mining equipment.

As you explore the vast open world, you'll encounter a variety of terrains and weather conditions, making each mining expedition a unique and unpredictable experience. The physics engine adds an extra layer of realism, simulating the weight and movement of the mining equipment, as well as the dynamics of the soil and rocks.

[h2]The Thrill of Discovery[/h2]

One of the most satisfying aspects of Gold Rush: The Game is the sense of discovery. When you uncover your first speck of gold, your heart will race with excitement. Every nugget you find brings a sense of accomplishment and propels you forward in your quest for riches. The game does an excellent job of capturing the highs and lows of the gold mining process, from the initial anticipation to the gratification of a successful operation.

[h2]User-Friendly Interface[/h2]

Gold Rush: The Game features an intuitive and user-friendly interface that makes it accessible to both seasoned gamers and newcomers alike. The controls are easy to learn, and the game provides helpful tutorials and tips to guide you through each stage of the gold mining process. Whether you're an experienced gamer or a novice, you'll quickly find yourself immersed in the world of gold mining.

[b]Pros[/b]

[list]
[*]Immersive and realistic gameplay that captures the essence of gold mining
[*]Stunning graphics and attention to detail that bring the game world to life
[*]A wide range of activities and challenges to keep you engaged and entertained
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]

[list]
[*]The initial learning curve might be steep for players who are new to simulation games
[/list]

In conclusion, Gold Rush: The Game is an exceptional virtual gold mining experience that offers hours of captivating gameplay and a genuine sense of adventure. The attention to detail, the realistic mechanics, and the thrill of discovery all come together to create an immersive and enjoyable gaming experience. Whether you're a fan of simulation games, a history buff, or simply someone looking for a unique gaming experience, Gold Rush: The Game is definitely a want-to-have game!

They removed two bypasses allowing you to add gold or cash as 'cheats' which would then flag your file so you couldn't compete. Many of us don't care about the fake leaderboard.   Then they encoded game files so people couldn't just add money to their game to actually use mechanics, see end game; or reality forbid, replace a game state when they changed the files that are now no longer readable.  Again, it still flagged at the leader board so you couldn't "cheat" that way and never could since 2018.

How about you put the save files back to un-encrypted so those of us that want to get all of our game-state back, or get to end game and not waste 100hours who don't care about a leaderboard of nothing can do so?

Or at least give us the password for the file so we can do it ourselves, which would then flag so if the people who don't understand can't waste time with false bug reports because they altered other file aspects (the purported reason for locking the game files instead of just asking if people changed them).

Just like mining for gold, don't set your expectations too high or you will be disappointed. The single biggest issues are optimization, this is a necessity as it just feels slow in general. NPC's? Yeah, nothing there. Hiring workers is cool, but you can't see them, interact with them, or even watch them work so that kinda sucks. The Tutorial is not very good, many steps are missed when "learning" the game so be prepared to just figure stuff out at first.

What this game really needs is for workers to be active in the mine assisting in operations so you don't feel so alone, like filling the truck with pay dirt or driving the pay dirt to the plant, something, anything showing actual involvement in the operation. Multiplayer would probably be cool if you like playing that style. And the mine site buildings don't seem to have any doors, so no wonder why they are abandoned... I wonder if people died inside or just never made it in to begin with? We'll never know I suppose.

Some bugs(?) include trailers being detached when fast traveling. Like the back of the truck getting high-centered on the mobile water tank. But you can also jump in the bed of the truck and walk with the brake off and the truck will move progressively which is really weird, so real-world physics are not part of the game. Bulldozing dirt is not very effective as the mechanics of this are strange and clunky. And heavy machinery tends to get high-centered on small lumps of dirt that would normally just squish away which can be a 5 minute journey of up-up-down-down-left-right-left-right-up-down.... you get the idea.

Overall, it is a fun game if you like to grind, and grind, and grind, and grind.... and grind. Everything takes forever, even with fast travel. The mechanics could use some serious polishing, particularly the physics of pretty much everything. And not being able to place the wash plant wherever you want is a bit disappointing. But hey, it's a game and I find it enjoyable for wasting time, so go dig some pay dirt and find some gold.

Gold Rush: The Game is an exciting and challenging game that takes players into the exciting world of gold mining.

One of Gold Rush's standout features is its realistic equipment and mechanics. Players must purchase and operate heavy machinery such as excavators, dump trucks, and a car wash to extract gold from the ground. Each machine has its quirks and requires its own specific set of skills to operate effectively.

The game also features a number of realistic challenges and obstacles that players must overcome in order to succeed. For example, players must manage their budget, maintain their equipment, and deal with breakdowns and mechanical failures.

 Another feature I love about Gold Rush is the exploration and discovery aspect of the game. Players must locate areas with high concentrations of gold, which requires careful surveying and prospecting. Once they find a promising location, they need to set up their operations and start mining the precious metal.

 Gold Rush also features a variety of game modes, including Career mode where players start out as a small miner and work their way up to larger farms, and a Sandbox mode that allows for more creativity and experimentation.

 Finally, Gold Rush's graphics and sound design are top-notch, immersing players in the beautiful and rugged Alaskan landscape. The sound effects of the machines and the sound of the river add to the realistic overall experience.

 All in all, Gold Rush: The Game is an extremely engaging and well-designed simulation game that offers a unique look into the exciting and challenging world of gold mining. Its realistic mechanics and challenges ensure players must strategize and work hard to succeed, making it an extremely rewarding and satisfying gaming experience.

My advice ?- don't expect too much from this game . Just like the 100,000 hopeful prospectors who stampeded to the Yukon in 1896 in difficult ,dangerous and often fatal conditions and found nothing to show for their effort at the end of the journey. 
I bought the game because i was a fan of the TV series, and just wanted to pan for gold - which i did and was mildly successful . Just remember , panning for gold is and always was a hard , lonely and rather boring job for very little reward. If the dev's introduced multiplayer it would make the game far more interesting and less lonely but that doesn't look like happening now after nearly 6 years of waiting.
 For now, the game has all the equipment you need to go much further than just panning , and has some appeal if your interested in hunting for gold on your own , but gets boring -  ultra fast . All things considered ,  for what you get the price of the game is fair IMHO .

I bought this game way early on because I like the Gold Rush TV series. I've played through the game, owned and mined every claim. A couple updates have definitely improved the game, and it is a horrible Gold Mining Sim at best. There is nothing about this game that is relative to the show. There isn't a single NPC in the game from start to finish. The intro should be you waking from a coma after a virus wiped out every organism except you, and for some reason you want to get $$$.

The Gold Rush TV series is all about the politics of managing a crew and mining in the Yukon, there's none of this in the game. I even hesitate to call this game a mining Sim, because it is so inaccurate, and unrealistic. On top of that, this game is so rigid and restricted with your capabilities, that every playthrough is pretty much the same.
A fun game for what it is, just dont go in with super high expectations

Most sim games like this are very generic and just feel like a simplified version of the real life task.  I feel Gold Rush works to give you the real life experience as you are always feeling like you are just getting into the groove then your equipment breaks and you have to run to town to get the parts to fix the equipment to resume the dig for gold.  What could have been a boring digging experience tends to offer the right amount of stress while offering a challenge to expand your operation and grow your empire.  The downside to the game is I feel once I have acquired all the equipment the game I lose interest not even wanting to buy other lands as they are a big grind away, just to continue the grind.  Maybe I missing something since I burn out though. Overall great game that is challenging and relaxing at the same time.

If you've tried this before but refunded it due to the horrible performance now is the time to give it another look because they finally updated the Unity engine! It runs great now when it used to stutter on low settings. Loading in areas would take forever too and even that is faster now. Much more enjoyable game now that it runs smoothly with higher settings on my lower spec system. (3200G/RX570).

Give it another chance! Have a good one.

Things to know before buying.

Dead game. No content since launch, and minimal effort to support / address game breaking issues (low earth orbit excavators, for example...)

Leaderboards are all they do, and those are poorly communicated and have profoundly shallow content - get a random claim for $0, unspecified bonuses to unspecified "stats" (wtf are those in this game?) 

Terrible visual glitches when digging - entire walls and floor textures disappear. 

Dev will never support mods - something vague about the agreement / contract with Discovery...

Game's a cashgrab and the store page is extremely misleading, to the point where the advertised content and support is flat out false. 

There is no "new content", free or otherwise, since Frank at launch.

Still, it's enjoyable to play every so often, but I regret paying full price for it. Recommend waiting until Steam gives it 80% off.

Gold Rush: The Game is a realistic simulation of gold mining that provides an immersive experience. The player assumes the role of a contemporary gold miner and is entrusted with exploring the wide wilderness, looking for gold, and establishing mining operations. The game's realistic equipment, beautiful visuals, and hard gameplay mechanics create a feeling of satisfaction when gold is successfully mined. The game's attention to detail and accurate depiction of the gold mining process make it an excellent option for simulation game enthusiasts and anyone interested in the gold mining sector. Gold Rush: The Game is a well-designed, entertaining, and fun simulation game.

Do I like this game? Yes. It's enjoyable but you might be thinking to yourself "Why the negative review if he likes the game?"


This is why. 


This game, from the start should've had a multiplayer/co-op. People asked the devs over at Coder Horizon if multiplayer is coming and this is what they had to say. 

"We here at Code Horizon know that the community would love to have Multiplayer as part of the game. Unfortunately, it’s not possible for us to implement without rewriting 50% of the game. Instead, we’re continuously working on other features." 

Code Horizon doesn't want to rewrite "50%" of their code for US. The ones who are supplying money into their pockets. 

What "other features" have we seen? 

Nothing. 

We have ONE dlc pack and it's honestly trash and shows their laziness. They add "Frankenstein" which is just a conveyor strapped to the top of an excavator. Because trying to move dirt to a dump truck and to the wash plant takes almost 20 minutes. The other addons with in the pack are just 2 trommels and 2 rocker shakers or whatever they are. Don't know. Don't care. 


Also a full dump truck gives you about 30 seconds to refill and dump into the rock-shaker because the wash plant moves very VERY fast. Almost too fast for a single player title. 

If you are going to have the wash plant move that fast and have the map at this scale, we NEED a co-op because the game gets V E R Y boring with just ONE PERSON running around to trying to rush a "gold mine". 

How can you get the backing of Discovery and not see that they have almost 20 people running those mines out in Alaska.....But you focus on single player....how f****** sad. 


Code Horizon. Get off your lazy high horse and start working on either getting multiplayer set up for this game or put out a new multiplayer mining game with actual license from CAT, VOLVO and so on.



To you the buyer that is interested in this game. I would honestly wait for "Gold Hunters" to be completed and buy that game instead. Even with this game onsale it's just not worth it. Save your money for "Gold Hunters". 

The game looks better, will have multiplayer and the devs won't worry about "Having to rewrite 50% of the games code" for a better overall player experience.

Even though I have 51 hours in this game they are probably some of the most problematic hours possible.
It all started in like 2020 when I first got it, my computer couldn't run the game it would basically just crash, then when i got a new computer in 2022 it worked to a certain extent if you minus the lag. and just a few months ago I got a new graphics card (rtx 2070 super not the best not the worst) and I have played these last couple of days and it is completely broken for some reason if I tab out the game within 20 mins at random it will just black screen and I can not day anything but turn my computer off and back on, BUT SOMETIMES ITS EVEN WORSE I have to unplug my graphics card like unscrewing it taking off power pulling it out then loading up computer like that and then turning off again and putting back in which is the most painful thing ever. There is no way of stopping it and this is the only game that I know of that does this I tried so many things and nothing changed it so I am finally gonna put this game to rest after the most painful hours playing a game. If you don't experience this then great as the concept of this game is cool but not the best execution especially without the feature of multiplayer, the devs should really make another game of gold rush but after learning from this one it will be better, oh well just my rant

fun game
VERY realistic and relaxing

Parts of the game are oddily satisfying, however there seems to be a gap in some areas of tech. Other areas seem to be tedious purely for the sake of being tedious.

You go from tier 1 to tier 2 & you lose the ability to find random gold nuggets,  But then when you get to tier 3 with an excavator, you're back to finding nuggets. ?????

The amount of effort you need to put into dumping dirt into the mobile washer is ridiculous, You're constantly trying to dump dirt into this thing but its too tall to get a good angle so you kinda have to bug it a bit. then after about 30min of filling it you get a whopping 100grams of gold. and to upgrade to the next tier you need hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Hiring workers seems to be the most ridiculous of all. You get a random hirable who you can't really confirm his job that much, hire the dude & he can work the pan. cool......but he doesn't do anything. Nor does he even appear. I read online his job is only to replace mats, but mine wasn't even doing that. so i fired him and hired the next guy, who is a mechanic. I am spending 1,600$ per day or so for this guy and i don't even know what HES doing.

I just want to hire more workers to ease my workload. I have no idea why they don't just dump a list of workers and let us upgrade them over time.

All n all, the game scratches an itch. It does the whole 'realistic gold hunter' deal very well, but some of the minor mechanics are just dumb.

This game is a Gold mining simulation that takes place in a sandbox world.  Machines can break down, and you can level up your mining system through 5 tiers. What a frustrating game to play.  It can be pretty fun if you're a fan of the TV show Gold Rush, but the fun went away the longer I played.  Virtually all of the machinery and work mechanisms have glitches that cause infuriating results at times, especially when items that you purchased disappear or become trapped in a spot where they can't be recovered.  Trailers disappear while attached to the truck and mysteriously appear at whatever restore point assigned for that item.  Once, all my extra equipment ( purchased as replacements for when equipment broke) all fell right through the storage shelves they had been placed on and ended up underneath the bottom shelf.  I spent about 20 minutes in recovering about 90% of the items. The others couldn't be retrieved.  

On several occasions, I managed to be catapulted into space and then dropped back into an area where I had never been, or the whole screen became a mosaic mess for several seconds.  Another occasion, the equipment stopped working correctly and caused all my hard earned pay dirt to just disappear when it was put into the Magnetite Separator.  The fix for the problem was to log out of the game, log out of Steam, and then restart Steam.

If you read other reviews of the game, you quickly begin to understand that anybody who's played the game quite a bit is pretty dissatisfied how the developers of the game never really made any attempt to fix the glitches that ruin the game.  They continue to put out new seasons DLCs but are unresponsive on social media.  Much as I liked the game, in spite of all the glitches, it eventually becomes tiresome dealing with mechanisms that don't work correctly.
A tip to new buyers you should watch the tv show to get some good tips

It's pretty fun. Game by design begs for multiplayer though. Beware if you're using an RTX series card. I bought the game when I had a 1070 and it ran fine, but once I upgraded to a 3070 the frames just disappeared. From what I can gather the game isn't optimized to run on RTX  cards and there is no fix or patch for this. The only solution I've run across is to turn shadows off and this did fix the issue of frame loss for me. Other than that if you like economy driven games where you spend money to make money faster, this is pretty good. 

There's a lot of nuances in the game I really enjoy, like buying water filters, oil filters, hoses having a certain range to them, etc. Little stuff like that makes it FEEL more real. Because these are things that you would have to buy and deal with in a real world setting. I can see how this would be off putting to some people but it's a lure for me more than anything. 

I never watched a lot of Gold Rush, but this doesn't feel like it relates much to that other than the theme of mining for gold in the Yukon. Seems like the tie in was done more or less just to try and ride on the shows popularity. 

For what it is though I'd say I got $20 worth of entertainment out of it so far.

I don't know what to say about this game other than it's fun, but repetitive. 

It's Single Player only. There are 100 different tasks for you to do around your mine, and you have to do it all by yourself. You can hire workers, but they don't actually do anything except maybe change out your mats in 1 hog pan. Running all the equipment, washing the gold, everything, you have to do yourself. It's time consuming to say the least, but if you like simple casual games where you do all the work and just enjoy the heavy equipment and digging for gold, then this just might be for you. As you can see, I've logged 214 hours into this game. I have honestly only once ever made it to the second plot. All the other times, I still never finished mining the first plot.

I've owned this game for a while now and have played it on and off but i can say that this game has a slow start if you don't know what to by or skipped the tutorial, it takes a bit to start after some time but once you get going it gets easier. The idea of new content coming out sounds great but it has been some time since there has been a major update that impacted the way you dug for gold, each update has been U.I., bug and peace of mind things or just released cosmetic items for the season winners. Don't get me wrong it's great the top preformer's get stuff but it's becoming repeative and lack luster.

Now for the problems I've seen and have experienced, this game is laggy at best and will crash on you more times than you can count if you don't have a mid to high tier computer lets not forget the graphic bugs that happen when dig deep or when you use certain camera angles. Like I said earlier it gets repeative and you spend long hours just digging away, there hasn't been any major updates that were game changing or awe inspiring to make me want to play this game more than I already have, but I conclude with this, this game is not worth the full price, get it on sale or if it's gifted to you sure go for it play it but in the end it's not worth the 20 some dollars their charging now. Like someone said in their review, these devlopers may not care anymore about this game and may be using it as a get rich quick scheme at this point.

I used to like this game quite a bit but after getting back to it after some computer issues, it has been ruined. It was never the glitch fest that it is now. Previously, I was able to put everything together with no issues at all. Now just trying to get the washplant together, I have pieces inside of each other and most of the equipment that makes it all unusable. just trying to get in the excavator launches it into orbit. I don't know what happened, but this game has become horrible and unplayable. In 2 real life days I haven't been able to do the basics of getting the washplant together, and it should take a couple hours tops. An updated view-
 After a long time with this game, I have to change my view. They have added some things here and there but overall the lack of innovation, and the inability to push this title forward has really been disappointing. Still to this day the dirt physics are horrible and all the gold mats/shakers etc still equalize. There is no variance in gold levels in mats. There is still a disconnect with the work you put in versus the end product. You don't even get to see gold until you go to blacksmith. One of the biggest issues is the tremendous failure to make this title multiplayer/Coop. Even to this day they don't want to hear anything about it. This is incompetency and lack of vision on many levels. They got to a point that they just fell in a rut and decided that would just become season overseers. You might be able to enjoy this for a short period at deep discount.

Beware, this is a mining game. You better like digging. Limited scope and equipment makes this one for the hardcore player. A good sim but lacks depth of gameplay and game assets.

Do I recommend this game... No not at all.
This TV show derived game like most games derived from TV or film is a mess of frame drops and poor design, it can barely run at the bests of times even with a fairly stout machine on low settings due to its frankly unappealing optimisation, the lack of a multiplayer also is a nail in this four year old game as it would smoothen out the clunky, slow, tedious and repetitive dull game that it is. The controls are a mess and are all over the place for default settings and get worse when you add a gamepad into the mix to try and help out the mechanics of the loader and excavator controls but even then I found it confusing and even at times frustrating. Code horizons even though a fairly young developer of games seems to have missed the mark for a simulator or even an arcade style game with this one. And to add I bought this game on launch and to me it seems like the devs have just abandoned it or are just not listening to people that are trying to tell them that it needs something more done to it. 

Overall for this game in my opinion its not worth the money, the poor quality of the game is a bad sign for what is to come of this developer and I hope that this game isn't their downfall and make something to blow all of us away.

I so much wanted to love this. I've been eyeing the game for years - I knew it had issues, but was hoping that, one day, it'd get some love from the devs and become the game it should be.
Yesterday, I decided to risk it, and bought the game.  Today I got a refund.

I'm sort of at a loss as to how the devs pulled off the mess they have managed to make here. Perhaps the best way to start explaining how oddly broken this game is is to point out that I get a steady 120 fps in most of the game - except when I don't, like at the blacksmiths, where I get 6 fps.  Yup, 6 - for no discernible reason.

The graphics, on ultra, are bland and washed out.  The sun is a simple off-white disc in the sky.  Shadows pop in to existence about 10m from the character. There are huge areas of the map you can't walk on, for no good reason.  The game stops dead for several seconds every 100m or so as you move around, to load - again, for no discernible reason.  The default mouse sensitivity suggests that no-one involved in the development or testing of this game has ever heard of a gaming mouse - or any mouse with more than 50 dpi; moving my mouse an inch or two caused me to spin around more than 3 times before I turned the sensitivity *way* down.  I usually turn the sensitivity *up* in games.

I could go on, but I won't.  I'm so sad that this is the 'best' game we have in this niche - and I am sickened that the devs threw away such an opportunity with such clear incompetence.  What a waste.

I know that PlayWay doesn't really care all that much about the quality of the games they produce, as long as the money keeps coming - but if I worked for them I'd be angry about this one.  If I worked for Code Horizon, I'd likely deny it to avoid the embarrassment of being associated with this mess.

If you really really want a gold mining sim, save yourself the pain and just wait until someone makes one - this isn't it.

After playing 200 hours i can truly say it was fun at the beginning but got super boring cause of no additional content and the devs don't listen to the community. The game has so much potential but they just wont do anything with the game other then adding seasons and minor hot fixes.

Oh MY GOD! This "game". Jeeesus Christ. I played 12 hours so far. 8 a couple of moth ago. 4 recently. Both times I run into a game breaking bug. I'm not sure I want restart a new gameplay ever again. Game says it's running 130-150 fps, but it looks more like 20-30 at best. I would love it if it worked, but going to main menu crash, press Esc crash, loading part of the map crash. Pretty much any given moment you can expect a random crash. The tutorial? Where do I start. Make 100% sure you do and only do what it says, when it says. I had to reload multiple times, because it just didn't register that I already did in advance what it wanted. I love the concept, but this game as it stand worth not more than £5.

UPDATE:

As you can see. Since my initial review, I put in some hours. Yet I failed to acknowledge the effort the Devs did in order to fix the bugs. I think it's needless to say that there are almost no  more crashes. I had 1 or 2 in the last 300 hours. I just want to say: Thank You for this game, it's been my therapist for so long. Whenever I feel overwhelmed in life, I just fire up the good old Trommel and do some more digging.

In general, I love this game, even if it stuck in the early access stage (in fact, not officially)

Plus
- Very good atmosphere
- The digging, the way you grab soil looks right. Not realistic, but right.
- The existing machines are awesome
- Water pressure/quantity and electricity system (missing adjustment but looks good)
- Good motivation system. You need to dig a lot to achieve higher tier stuff.
- The shopping system, getting the equipment and putting it to work feels right. 

Minus
- Weird and unfinished physics. The water bucket annoyingly falls through the carry box instead at least snapping in and being locked. Equipment slips unrealistically, like slowly drifts sideways. The buckets... they should not tip so easily. 
- Where does the dirt coming out of the wash plant go? It is just gone mysteriously.
- There is a mobile generator, sized of a toolbox, which produces 500 kW and drinks like a liter per hour. That is a miracle! A 500 kW generator is a size of a smaller locomotive engine, weights several tons and drinks like 100 liters per hour. The electricity needs serious rebalancing, the mobile genset should do 5 kW, there should be a towable mid tier genset doing 50 kW and the big container, that should do 500 kW. Of course consumers rebalanced, such way that the small gen can handle the cleanout small table, mag sep, nuggetator, the mid tier gen could run the mobile washplant and so on. 
- Same with the water. 100000l towable tank? That would be 100 tons, good luck towing that with a car. Big pump doing 200 liters per minute? The hand moveable pump should do 1400-1500 liters per minute.
- Whoever comes up with kW/liter values in the game, should learn to use google and research. These equipment are based on real ones, just google the specs, and balance it to the in-game mechanics.
- Loans are insane. This is not the early gold rush...
- Time compression is used the wrong way. What is the point leaving it at the default 12x? That makes you 12 times less effective. Leaving it 12x means while you digging in real time for an hour, every machine consumes the amount required for 12 hours. That also ruins renting costs. Just why? Time compression should be 1x by default and it should be quickly adjustable when waiting for something. 
- The whole revenue/cost system appears to be intended to be balanced for the 12x speed in a weird way. But who wants to play with 12x speed? However in normal speed, fuel consumptions feel realistic, but power, liter and gold catch values are way off. I can make like $100K per hour? Real miners would be happy with a few thousand dollars per day.

Little more on the negative side, but I still love this game. It has very good potential, but looks abandoned at early access phase. Needs balancing, fixing and content both in mechanics (like different type of gold, washplant setup for the type, and optimal working, sluice slope, water quantity, rtc) and models (multiple type of  washplants, multiple mining equipment).  At least in form of DLC.

It is a very fun game, however I was not able to enjoy it properly and requested a refund because even though I've got a decently powerfull computer, with specs way above the recomended ones, my FPS often are lower than 10 for multiple seconds. Over all a very good and fun game if you like simulators but I can not recommend it because of the severe issues I had playing it.

The concept, intended mechanics and game loop are very engaging and leave plenty of room for you to optimize your production. 

[b]The Good:[/b]

* Control of the large equipment seemed good as well as using the various other equipment needed for mining was intuitive and seemed legit.
* Tweaking production and there is lots of work to do.

[b]The Bad:[/b] 

* It has a horrible frame rate.
* [strike]The Pickup truck physics and speed control is terrible. That's a shame because it could of been a fun part of the game. Instead, it makes you want to walk everywhere.[/strike] FIXED
* Can get grindy (becomes digging simulator)  

If you have a good computer, get it. If not, stay away.

Wait for more updates. The game is fun for a very niche market. Very repetitive (Journal tells you as much). Number of bugs/issues to get past:

Save game corruptions
Environment doesn't load after loading a game (successfully)
Game freezes at specific parts to render the rest of the map
Some parts of the Journal/DigTube aren't very clear with regards to equipment/machine requirements
Broke the game once when the tools in the back of my truck phased through the truck and "exploded" outward breaking the game
The use of a Reset button to reset your vehicle is a shoddy workaround for poor driving implementation
Filling your bucket with water and looking behind you while the animation is still going sometimes slingshots you in the direction you are facing.

The state this game is in is absolutely baffling. It's 4 or 5 years old and is horribly balanced. The grind is absolutely insane, and I'm the sort of person that loves grinding in games. I'm nearly 14 hours in and I still haven't completed part 2 of the tutorial, not even close. You get such a tiny amount of gold, for such an arduous amount of effort that you're sure you're doing something wrong. A quick search on the forums shows countless posts entitled "Am I doing something wrong?", but no you aren't, the game is just horribly balanced.

It's like the developers aren't even aware, and/or don't care either. Just one example is I got 3 achievements for gathering magnetite, 10, 100 and 1000. It takes an eye watering 35000 magnetite to get the first, the cheapest upgrade... It takes 75000 to get the next cheapest. What the filth flarin flarin filth is this nonsense?

That's without going into how poorly optimised the game is. As I said, it's 5 years old and it constantly stutters, and freezes for loading between areas. The strange thing is, the developers are still organising seasons or whatever so they're still around, they're just not addressing the glaring issues with this title.

I bought this game a few years back now and it was fun, I mean a lot of fun.
I reinstalled on my newer laptop as I felt like a solid sim game but things had changed. Dramatically.

Previously progression was steady and you felt like things were moving along however now I find out that workers don't work. I mean if I hired them in RL I would be pretty pissed if I was paying them and all they were doing was 8% of the work and only while I was the one doing the shovelling.

I chose to have the "nugget bonus" which originally felt a little cheap however when all the nugget dried up it was such a grind. Progress is hard and it feels like such a big leap from manual work to more automatic. The controls are not super nice to use which is not a huge deal for the most part however when to have to run between the hogbox and the dirt turning around and aim so that you tip the dirt it does not feel great.

Brings me to the lag... When I first got this it was smooth as, on a 4th gen i5, gtx1060, 8gb ram.
I have now an 9th gen i7, RTX 2060, 16gb ram and half the time is is smooth the other half is 2-3 frames a second. Loading times between areas is a nightmare also. I swear it was never this bad previously. It is all such a shame because it looks like everthing for this was going in the right direction and then I guess seasons happened and patches broke things and it looks like the Devs have no want to change anything about it. So for people that don't mind a grind, and perhaps some lag (not sure what the issue is here but perhaps not everyone gets it) then sure, go for it. But for a good sim game look for something else.

Additional: I jumped back in to give this game another chance. I found that the "worker" who was working previously on the hog pan mats is now not working. The spare mats in the holders have been double checked and are empty. I hope that a reload will fix this because honestly I want to like this game again.
It was good when it was in development, and now there are bugs and hackers and no new content coming up. It is a waste of time.

While it is fun at first, it becomes a chore to grind later on.
You are ALWAYS alone on the claim. "Workers" improve statistics on the equipment you assigned them to, take ages to "learn" how to remove more than two mats at a time and so on - which on top costs you a fortune...and then they might just quit.
It's an unfinished prototype with a lot of potential...if only the devs would care to add in "new free content"...
It's a blatant lie!
All you get is new online seasons with altered conditions. 
Mucho fun to start out everytime with a bucket and shovel...over and over again...

I've had this game for years and have had fun with it in the past, watching the Frankenstein update come in and conveyor belts were a great addition. Normally I would've suggested this game and I'm glad I waited to write this review as my views have changed. They removed the NPCs that help you with mining and now the workers only do specific things, most of which are not as useful as they should be. Also performance took a major hit making it unbearable to even play at this point, I used to run the game on Ultra settings averaging around 30-40 FPS but now the game runs at a whopping 3-10 FPS with only moments where it runs like it used to even with lower settings. I've uninstalled and reinstalled to clear cache since I couldn't find the cache file myself and even started a new game to get a clear save file to see if my equipment was lowering performance to no avail. IDK what to do with this at this point as I cant run the game smoothly as I've done before and running the entire mine by myself is a complete drag now and having multiple claims is utterly useless as you're only one person. IMO wait till a major performance update and hopefully they'll change their minds about NPCs or sell out to someone able to do multiplayer.

If you like lonely games with high complexity, this is your game.

I'm sorry Game Developers, please forgive me, but this game have the worst frames per second of all the 140 games I own in my library. Unity is a good engine, but it is also dangerous. You have to know how to setup the low graphics settings, otherwise, the graphics gets ugly but the FPS stays low all the time. Literally, doesn't matter witch settings I set, even -force-d3d9. On low settings, You have to use URP(not HDRP), disable all post-processing layers, LOD groups with Billboard Assets, and there are many good articles on the subject like this: https://gamedevelopertips.com/increase-performance-in-unity-games/   
Yes I know. BUY A NEW COMPUTER. I've heard that a million times already. My answer? Send me a new computer bought with YOUR money to my address. Best of luck to you. God bless

60 Hour Review: 

Great game as far as simulators go. definetly not a polished product and would still call this a beta phase at this point. I was disapointed that the DLC that is offered is not actually a part of the base game as these are really items that should have been in the base game and after buying the DLC confirmed this to be so. 

The game is a true occupational grinder as nothing in this title comes quick but that is part of the romance of this types of titles is that they actually make you work for it, from driving a vehicle to town, having to load an unload items, and set them up. I personally have spent 6 plus hours just setting up a wash plant setup in this game. 

This title is not of the quick of rage quit type set as again this is a grinding occupational simulator. I look forward to seeing what comes from this game in the future when the game is more polished.

Short answer: I would buy this game again. Long answer: this game is incredibly frustrating, but a ton of fun. It can get to be a dull grind, but there are many aspects of the game to keep it interesting for many hours. To me, if something can entertain me for hours, and I enjoyed it, and would do it again, I believe it is worth some amount of money in return.  I would LOVE to see updates or even a Gold Rush 2 with new claims, a much bigger variety of machines and equipment (this game does have the basics covered), possibly placing NPCs at the bank with a nice counter instead of interacting with a door, at the equipment store instead of the register, and at the machine store instead of the door, etc., possibly adding player skill levels to help with gold recover/loss, and more attention to the workers (if a worker is rejected, there are no other workers to choose from until the next set time comes for a new worker to appear - don't like this!). I'm still grinding away, and hope the devs are listening.

The game is decent but the lag causes the fps to drop below 10 while in town.  I have a 2080ti and a 9900K with 32Gb of RAM.  I should not be experiencing any issues with fps with a game like this.  Optimization needs to be revisited by the devs. I get 70 fps with Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020.  There is definitely an issue.

UPDATE:

After about 8 more hours on the game, it has not improved my opinion from my initial review.  The frame rate is glitchy, there are bugs associated with the physics causing one to lose things.  All-in-all this has potential, but in it's current state it's just aggravating in the sense that when I retrained a worker to do a different assignment, he lost the ability to do what he was initially good at.  That's ridiculous considering how much money it costs to retrain a worker. Also, there was no warnings, or documentation suggesting that the work would not be able to go back to his previous assignment. I definitely will not be adding additional time to this game until some significant updates are released (i.e. more information on putting things together and having the workers be effective, graphic optimization, etc.)

Initially I didn't recommend this game, but after giving it another go, I'm happy to change this to a recommended.

The graphics are fine, it isn't going to win any beauty awards but that's ok for what the point of the game is.

Early on you'll encounter lengthy pauses of several seconds while the game loads new terrain (while driving) Initially I saw this as a problem, and it is to a degree, but only if you spend a lot of time driving back and forth from town to plot. Once you're on the plot you won't encounter these loading pauses.

The sounds are decent, nice ambient music playing in the background can make this a calm, enjoyable experience.

One thing I would recommend is doing a bit of youtubing and reading the guide on here. The guide is good, but I still needed a bit more clarification on some things and that's where youtube comes into it.

So here's an interesting turn of events.

For the longest time there have been many people asking for a multiplayer feature for Gold Rush. However the developers made the game to be single player only. I actually supported this decision for a long time which anyone can see in the pinned thread for multiplayer.

So one day I posted:

[quote]
Rather than make this an MP game.. It would make more sense to make the "next" game MP from the ground up..

In fact... someone thought of it.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/1082450/Gold_Hunter/
[/quote]

This of course included a link to Gold Hunter which is a game in development that offers similar gold mining but.. with Multiplayer...  a feature many were asking for.

Several months passed by and out of the blue I received a permanent ban to the GR forums. it was odd that it was for the post above. but it had " publicity" as the reason for the perma ban.  Strange.. a perma ban for posting a link to another game on steam of the same genre and on topic since this was a discussion about Multiplayer.

Clearly the developers are highly threatened by this new game which is not even released yet. So much so that without any warning they issue perma bans to silence any notion of competition.

Well if nothing else, it speaks volumes about the developers character and temperament.

This game as stated is enjoyable and relaxing, but as you progress, the worker system is not enough for most to want to continue, what i make a bunch of money and gold and have what to look forward too? more employees, no. bigger better equipment, no same equipment thats been in game since start basically. dredging, no. What you experience in the first claim is what you get the rest of the game, just better gold, but its deeper. You implemented breakdowns? cool realistic, yes , but too frequent and annoying, again if there was a mechanic worker that would be a better choice, also limiting me to only few vehicles on claim, dumb, if my rock truck broke down, id need a mechanic to fix it and grab another in the meantime.

 Listen this is a good game if you are really about that single player just wanna chill game and think that runnin an entire mining operation alone is your bag. For the masses though Gold Hunter is right around the corner, and it will have a long way to go, the mechanics arent nearly as polished as this and the team is small rn but with mp already and much much much more content planned than this it is sure to be around for a long time to come, dredging, ice mining, basically all aspects of the gold mining process are planned.






*Edit: after over a hundred hours and taking my time between sessions for more upodates, these devs continue to improve the game to the best of their ability for a SP game, it is still enjoyable and the leaderboards gives you something to push foreward and compete, we need this one to get alot of bugs out then when they make GR2 there will be MP and will be that much more enjoyable. Mary Berry's Banoffee Pie:
Ingredients

For the base

150g/5½ oz digestive biscuits (about 10)
75g/2¾oz butter
For the toffee filling
75g/2¾oz butter
75g/2¾oz light muscovado sugar
1 x 397g/14oz full-fat condensed milk (see tip)
1 tsp vanilla extract
For the topping
300ml/10fl oz double cream
3 small just-ripe bananas, sliced
50g/1¾oz dark chocolate, melted or cocoa powder

Method

Line the base of a deep 20cm/8in spring form tin with baking paper.

To make the base, crush the biscuits to fine crumbs and melt the butter over a low heat. Pour into a bowl and mix to combine. Spoon into the base of the tin and press down with the back of a spoon until level. Place in the fridge for 15 minutes.

To make the filling, heat the butter and sugar in a small non-stick saucepan and stir over a low heat until combined. Add the condensed milk and bring to the boil, stirring for 2–3 minutes – do not over-boil or it will become grainy and fudge-like. Add the vanilla and pour into the tin. Place in the fridge for at least 1 hour.

Whip the cream in a bowl until soft peaks form.

Arrange the banana slices in neat rounds on top of the toffee. Spoon or pipe the cream on top and level. Set in the fridge for an hour.

Remove from the tin, and zig zag the melted chocolate over the top or dust with cocoa powder.

Great concept, poorly executed. When I bought the game pre-purchase videos etc indicated that this game would allow me to build up a gold company empire by starting with a shovel and working my way up to a major gold operation with employees operating equipment and pulling in the $. After purchasing it, I worked my way up from the river panning to a major operation, but all levels had one theme in common - I - myself had to do every task, The employees in game just gave benefits, but did no actual work. This meant that I had to shovel the dirt with my front-end loader, move the dirt from equipment to equipment and sell the gold, More to the point, building the business to multiple claims would not work because you can only work one at a time, and employees do not work the others. Net result, you spend 95% of your time shoveling dirt, 5% of your time processing, selling, upgrading etc. If you are looking for an ultra-realistic game where you are the permanent worker doing everything, and your ok just operating a front end loader or shovel 95% of the game this is the game for you. On the other hand, if you are looking for a game where you want to build a major gold empire - then pass on this game and look elsewhere.
